Problem.Question: Two opposite charged spheres, Q and -Q, 20 cm apart, attract each other with a force of 22.50 N. Determine the charge Q on the sphere. What force results from each of the following changes, considered separately?
Choice: Both charges are doubled and the distance remains the same.
The separation is increased to 30 cm.
if one has twice the charge as the other
What is the magnitude of the force, a 1.5 × 10<sup>-6</sup> C charge exerts on a 3.2 × 10<sup>-5</sup> C charge located 1.5 m away?
Problem.Remark: The "Force" between the two charges can be visualized by adjusting the parameters in the 3D environment below. The magnitude of the force of repulsion for the last problem, F = 0.19 N

Problem.Question: Three point charges, q<sub>1</sub>, q<sub>2</sub> and q<sub>2</sub> lie along a straight line such that the resultant force on the middle charge q<sub>3</sub> is zero.
Choice: Positive charge q<sub>1</sub> = 16 µ C is at x = 4.00 m and the positive charge q<sub>2</sub> = 6 µ C is at origin. Determine the coordinate of the charge q<sub>3</sub>
If q<sub>1</sub> is negatively charge where will the resultant force on the charge q<sub>3</sub> be zero. (Case I)
If q<sub>1</sub> and q<sub>2</sub> are of equal magnitude but of opposite charge. (Case II)
Problem.Remark: Solve the quadratic equation to obtain the answer

Problem.Question: Consider three point charges, q<sub>1</sub>, q<sub>2</sub> and q<sub>2</sub> located at the corners of a right isoceles tiangle.
Choice: q<sub>1</sub> =  q<sub>3</sub> = 5 µ C, q<sub>2</sub> = -2.0 µ C and lenght of the sides a = 0.1 m.  Calculate the reultant force exerted on q<sub>3</sub>
Case I- Visualise the resultant forces on the individual charges
Case II- Calculate the reultant force exerted on q<sub>3</sub> for various senarios
Problem.Remark: Resultant force, F<sub>3</sub> = F<sub>23</sub> + F<sub>13</sub> (Vector Addition)

Problem.Question: In a Roller Coaster Loop, where does the rider feels (a) the "lightest" and (b) the "heaviest"
Choice: (a) At the bottom of the Loop and (b) At the top of the Ferris wheel
(a) At the top of the Loop and (b) At the bottom of the Ferris wheel
The centripetal acceleration is constant throughout the wheel so the riders feel their "true" weight at all the positions, never lighter or heavier
There is not enough information given to solve this problem.
Problem.Remark: Consider the "Normal Force" exerted on the rider. > At the bottom of the loop, <b>N</b is the largest and makes the rider feel the heaviest where as at the top <b>N</b is the smallest

Problem.Question: Calculate the normal force exerted on the rider, weighing 100 kg at top of the loop - N1 and at bottom of the loop N2 if the diameter of the loop is 26m.Time taken, T, to complete 1 revolution of the loopp is 30 s.
Choice: N1 = 7.5 x 10<sup>5</sup> N and N2 = 12.1 x 10<sup>5</sup> N
N1 = 9.23 x 10<sup>5</sup> N and N2 = 10.37 x 10<sup>5</sup> N
Problem.Remark:
Determine the velocity of the rider (v = 2πr/T), and then calculate the radial acceleration (ar = v/r). At top position N1 = M(g - ar)
and at bottom position N2 = M(g + ar)

Problem.Question: A footballer kicks a ball on horizontal ground giving it an initialvelocity of 25 ms<sup>-1</sup> at an angle of 35° to the horizontal
Choice: Where will the ball be 1.2 seconds after it is kicked?
What will be the greatest height reached by the ball
Where will the ball land?
Problem.Remark: Horizontal motion, x = V cos θ t and Vertical motion, y = V sin & theta; t - 1/2 g t<sup>2</sup>

Problem.Question: A boy throws a stone from the top of a cliff into the sea. When the stone leaves his hand it is travelling horizontally at a velocity of 10 ms<sup>-1</sup> at an angle of 35° to the horizontal
Choice: How long will it take the stone to reach the sea, a distance 8 metres below?
How far from the bottom of the cliff will it be when it enters the sea
What will its vertical velocity be when it hits the water?
Problem.Remark: Horizontal motion, x = V cos θ t and Vertical motion, y = V sin & theta; t - 1/2 g t<sup>2</sup>
